description: Continuation of Chemistry 101. The second term stresses the thermodynamic approach to chemical reactions, electrochemical processes, and reaction rates and mechanisms. It includes special topics in chemistry.
name: GENERAL CHEMISTRY II

values.comments:
General Chemistry II, CHEM 102, is a continuation of CHEM 101. The topics covered include thermodynamic approaches to chemical reactions, electrochemical processes, and reaction rates and mechanisms, as well as other special topics in Chemistry.

Most students found this course to be “incredibly organized” and “well-taught,” even though it was quite difficult.

Many students considered Profess Sneddon to be “one of the best professors” they’ve had at Penn, “[he] really good at communicating course material” as well as highly approachable and friendly. Professor Sneddon held “plenty of office hours” and seemed to have a “genuine interest in the students as well as the material.” Professor Sneddon’s use of real world examples proved to be successful in maintain student interest during lectures. Students also stated that Professor Sneddon’s efficient use of Internet resources, such Blackboard, to post assignments, homework solutions, and past exams was very helpful as well.

Many students said that even though Professor Sneddon went over a lot of examples during class, “reading the textbook is still essential.” Most students found the course to be quite a bit of work, but said that the problem sets due every week were very helpful in keeping them on top of the material. 

Most students found the exams to be highly challenging, in that the tests “didn’t always reflect very well the practice problems given.” However, a small number of students voiced different concerns, claiming that Professor Sneddon made the tests “look like problems he has either given us in class, or assigned to us in homework.”

General Chemistry II, CHEM 102, is a continuation of CHEM 101. The topics covered include thermodynamic approaches to chemical reactions, electrochemical processes, and reaction rates and mechanisms, as well as other special topics in Chemistry.

Many students stated, “[it was] difficult to get engaged in the lectures for this course.” Some students felt that they were able to “get a lot out of this course,” while other students felt that they had “learned very little.” Many students also felt that the class was “full of a lot of extra information” which students weren’t sure if they had to know.

Students found Professor Fitts to be an “extremely nice man,” but many students complained that he was “unable to stimulate interest in the subject,” causing lectures to be “dry.” Professor Fitts taught the course by doing derivations and defining terms on the blackboard. While this teaching method worked for some students, many felt that Professor Fitts “rarely explained what was going on conceptually,” oftentimes causing confusion among students.

The great majority of students found tests to be “reasonable and fair,” containing material taken from lecture and homework problems. However, many students felt that most of what they learned, they had to teach themselves from reading the textbook, which was quite helpful. Because of this, many students felt that the course took up a lot of time and was a lot of work.

General Chemistry II, CHEM 102, is a continuation of CHEM 101. The topics covered include thermodynamic approaches to chemical reactions, electrochemical processes, and reaction rates and mechanisms, as well as other special topics in Chemistry. 

Most students felt that they learned a lot from this “fast-paced” course. They found the course to be enjoyable, “well-organized,” and “in-depth.” The great majority of students agreed that Professor Composto did a good job and was a “strong professor.” Professor Composto was “always willing to hold office hours to help improve understanding.” Students also felt that he made class interesting by using many different teaching techniques: PowerPoint slides, examples/derivations on the board, videos/animations, real life models, live demonstrations, as well as discussions about current events and real world applications.

The great majority of students stated that Professor Pietrovito did an “excellent job” of teaching the material and was highly capable of communicating the subject matter. Professor Pietrovito’s office hours were very helpful and students felt that he “knew the material like the back of his hand.” Many students especially appreciated the supplementary notes Professor Pietrovito posted on Blackboard, which most found to be “insanely helpful.”

However, some students found the course to have quite a bit of homework. Students felt that it was highly necessary to do all of the assigned homework because it really prepared one for the exams. Most students liked the structure of the course in that there were no quizzes and there was an option to drop an exam.
